questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest shows bilateral wheeze. The image of a characteristic finding in the sputum is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological image showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria, and mild hepatomegaly. A biopsy specimen seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of systemic Amyloidosis. The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized light, diagnostic of amyloidosis.

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Kidneys are the most frequently involved with heart being second. Cardiac involvement is the leading cause of death from AL amyloidosis. 

Renal amyloidosis usually manifests as proteinuria, often in the nephrotic range, and is associated with hypoalbuminemia, secondary hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and edema or anasarca. 

The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with (A) focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material, and (B) apple-green birefringence under polarized light, diagnostic of amyloidosis. 

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows blue stained hepatocellular iron.

 

Acid mucin is stained by Alcian blue. 

 

The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

questions.text: The histopathological section of the cardiac tissue of an elderly man shows some pigmentation as seen below. Which of the following intracellular accumulations is it likely to be?
questions.solution:
The brown intracellular accumulation that can be seen in this patient is lipochrome (lipid). It is also known as lipofuscin or wear-and-tear pigment.

It is brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain. It is seen in normal ageing patients. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.  

Lipofuscin (brown lipid):

  • Derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes.
  • Not injurious to the cell or its functions.
  • Indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.
  • Seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes.
  • Prominent in the liver, brain, and heart of ageing patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia.

Other options:

Option A: Dutcher bodies are pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C: Mallory bodies are seen in

  1. Alcoholic steatohepatitis
  2. Wilson disease
  3. Primary biliary cirrhosis
  4. Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis(NASH)
  5. Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Option D: Cholesterol deposits are seen in atherosclerosis, xanthomas.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with a history of morning headaches, vomiting, and lethargy for the past 6 months.  MRI scan showed a contrast-enhancing nodule in the cerebellum. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image. The tumors were positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a child presenting with symptoms of increased intracranial tension with an image that shows Rosenthal fibers are suggestive of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a brain tumour that occurs more often in children and young adults. These tumours are usually slow-growing and benign. The majority of neoplasms are located in the cerebellum. However, they can also appear around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.

On brain MRI, it can be identified as a contrast-enhancing nodule. On microscopy, it has very limited brain invasion compared to infiltrative astrocytomas. The tumour is made up of bipolar cells with hair-like projections forming a dense fibrillary meshwork. These cells are positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The characteristic features of this tumour are the presence of Rosenthal fibres and eosinophilic granular bodies. A Rosenthal fibre is a corkscrew-shaped eosinophilic inclusion while eosinophilic granular bodies are mulberry-shaped inclusions.

In low-grade astrocytoma, surgical resection is the primary treatment modality, and in high-grade lesions, local irradiation is also done after surgical correction.

The below image shows pilocytic astrocytoma with Rosenthal fibers (arrows) and dense fibrillary meshwork.

Other options:

Option A- Ependymomas are the tumors that arise from the ependyma-lined ventricular system. The tumor cells have fibrillary processes and form gland-like round or elongated structures (rosettes and canals) that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal.

Option C- Medulloblastoma is a WHO grade IV aggressive tumor arising from the cerebellum. The tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes.

Option D- Oligodendroglioma is composed of tumor cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumor contains sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin, surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives them fried egg appearance. They contain a network of anastomosing capillaries, resembling chicken wire and also have calcifications.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: The structures shown in the below image are found in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows psammoma bodies. They are found in meningioma.

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include-

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma
  • Meningiomas.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors, usually attached to the dura. They are predominantly seen in females and in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2, which is an autosomal disorder associated with multiple meningiomas, schwannomas, and ependymomas.

They arise from the meningothelial cells or arachnoid cap cells. The most common karyotypic abnormality is the loss of the long arm of chromosome 22. Meningiomas often express hormone receptors (eg: Progesterone), hence, they may grow rapidly in pregnancy.

Meningiomas are rubbery, rounded, or bosselated dural masses. They compress the underlying brain tissue. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits. 

The tumor spreads in a sheet-like manner along the surface of the dura causing reactive hyperostotic changes in adjacent bones. They are mostly located in cerebral convexities. The lesions may be finely gritty due to numerous psammomatous calcification. 

Other options:

Option A: Russell bodies are cytoplasmic globular inclusions that are seen in multiple myeloma.

Option C: Verocay bodies are spindle cells that are arranged to form central “nuclear-free zones” ramified by palisading nuclei and are seen in Schwanomma.

Option D: Call-Exner bodies are diagnostic gland-like immature follicles that are filled with an acidophilic material and are seen in granulosa cell tumours of the ovary.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and histopathological findings showing caseating granuloma are suggestive of tuberculosis.

The microscopic picture shows the caseating granuloma. Eosinophilic necrotic debris known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells and lymphocytes can be seen. Epitheloid cells merge to form Langhan's giant cell where nuclei arranged in a horseshoe shape (a characteristic feature of tuberculosis). 

Clinically, tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, fever, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes.

Other options:

Option B- Leprosy presents with skin lesions and nerve involvement with loss of sensation.

Option C- Sarcoidosis shows giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions, non-caseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.

Option D- Syphilis shows thickened capsule/ hyperplasia of capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells.

questions.text: A 60-yr-old man presents with dyspnea and cough. Chest x-ray studies reveal irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is shown below. This patient may develop all the following diseases except__________.
questions.solution:
The image shows beaded rods of asbestos bodies (ferruginous bodies) seen in asbestosis. Asbestosis would not lead to laryngeal carcinoma. Lung carcinomas, colon carcinomas and mesotheliomas develop in workers exposed to asbestos.

The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. Asbestos generally occurs in 2 forms - Serpentine chrysotile and Amphibole. Amphiboles, though less prevalent than chrysotiles are more pathogenic and are involved in the occurrence of mesothelioma, a malignant tumour derived from the lining cells of the pleural surfaces.

In contrast to other inorganic dust, asbestos acts as a tumour initiator and a tumour promoter. Some of its oncogenic effects are mediated by reactive free radicals generated by the asbestos fibres.

Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multiple asbestos bodies. Asbestos bodies are golden-brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with a translucent center and consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material and arise when macrophages phagocytose asbestos fibers.

Other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes and are called ferruginous bodies.

Asbestosis begins as fibrosis around the respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts and most commonly arises in the lower lobe. Pleural plaques are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen that are often calcified and are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure.

Clinical features include,

  • Dyspnoea
  • Productive cough

The chest x-ray shows irregular linear densities in the lower lobes and a honeycomb pattern in advanced cases.

The disease may remain stable or progress to respiratory failure, Cor pulmonale and death.

Asbestos exposure is linked with 6 disease processes:

  • Parenchymal Interstitial Fibrosis ( Asbestosis)
  • Localised pleural plaques or rarely diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Recurrent pleural effusion
  • Lung carcinoma 
  • Malignant pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma 
  • Laryngeal cancer.

Cigarette smoking increases the risk of lung cancer in people with asbestos exposure.

Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic and chemical dusts (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde, penicillin products).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnoea. Echocardiography showed mitral stenosis with vegetation. The vegetation present on the mitral valve was excised and its HPE image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given HPE image depicts Aschoff bodies, suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis. During acute rheumatic fever, Aschoff bodies may be found in any of the three layers of the heart. 

Chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening and fibrosis of the valve leaflets, often with calcific deposits. Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques.

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish mouth appearance (button hole).

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.solution:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as “Faggot cells” (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).  

Since the question specifically asks about the cell, the best answer is Faggot cell (not Auer rods).

Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present numerously in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukaemia).

Other options:

  • The term flaming promyelocyte has been coined to describe cells that appear to be “breaking apart”, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix.
  • Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear “dusky” or “hazy” and are referred to as such.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia

The WHO system divides acute myeloid leukemia (AML) into several groups:

AML with certain genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes)

  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21 [t(8;21)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 16 [t(16;16) or inv(16)]
  • APL with the PML-RARA fusion gene
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 11 [t(9;11)]
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 6 and 9 [t(6:9)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 3 [t(3;3) or inv(3)]
  • AML (megakaryoblastic) with a translocation between chromosomes 1 and 22 [t(1:22)]
  • AML with the BCR-ABL1 (BCR-ABL) fusion gene*
  • AML with mutated NPM1 gene
  • AML with biallelic mutations of the CEBPA gene (that is, mutations in both copies of the gene)
  • AML with mutated RUNX1 gene*

*This is still a "provisional entity," meaning it is not yet clear if there's enough evidence that it is a unique group.

AML with myelodysplasia-related changes

AML related to previous chemotherapy or radiation

AML not otherwise specified (This includes cases of AML that do not fall into one of the above groups and is similar to the FAB classification.)

  • AML with minimal differentiation (FAB M0)
  • AML without maturation (FAB M1)
  • AML with maturation (FAB M2)
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukemia (FAB M4)
  • Acute monoblastic/monocytic leukemia (FAB M5)
  • Pure erythroid leukemia (FAB M6)
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (FAB M7)
  • Acute basophilic leukemia
  • Acute panmyelosis with fibrosis

Myeloid sarcoma (also known as granulocytic sarcoma or chloroma)

Undifferentiated and biphenotypic acute leukemias are not strictly AML, but are leukemias that have both lymphocytic and myeloid features. They are sometimes called mixed phenotype acute leukemias (MPALs).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings of starry sky appearance point towards a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma.

The biopsy image shows tumor cells with multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and high mitotic index closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (the "sky"). These cells have a high turnover rate. The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debr is, they are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris ( the "stars"). This produces a starry sky appearance, which is classical to Burkitt lymphoma. 

Burkitt lymphoma:

  • Most common NHL in children <15 years
  • Associated with translocation of MYC gene of chromosome 8 (Option A)
  • Translocations: t (8;14), t (2;8), t (8,22)
  • Three distinct clinical forms:
    • Endemic: affects children in Africa, affects the jaw, and maxilla and is EBV-associated (Option B)
    • Sporadic: in adults in Western countries 
    • Immunodeficiency associated: HIV infection
  • It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumour, Ki-67 stains 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67)

Histology: Starry sky pattern

Immunophenotype: 

  • The tumour cells express
    • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
    • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
    • Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
    • HLA-DR and CD43.
  • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumours.
    • Endemic BL are EBV positive, express CD21
    • Non-endemic BL in non-immunosuppressed patients are EBV negative and lack CD21 expression.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull shows multiple lytic lesions. Skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils as in the image below. Immunohistochemistry for S100, CD1a is also shown in the images below. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological image showing Langerhans cells with folded nuclei (image A),CD1a (image B),and positive S100 (image C), is suggestive of Langerhanscell histiocytosis (LCH).

LCH occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, calledLangerhans cells.Theirnormal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is theBRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized bysingle or multiple osteolytic bone lesionsandcan also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system.

LCH can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis(Letterer-Siwe disease) - mostly seen in infants
  • Unifocal and multifocal uni system Langerhans cell histiocytosis(eosinophilic granuloma) -The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called theHand-Schller-Christian triad - mostly seen in youngerchildren
  • Pulmonary LCH- mostly seen in adults

Clinical features includepain and swelling in the affected area. When calvarium is affected, it results in otitis media and mastoiditis. Spinal involvement results in compression fractures and neurological involvement. Vertebral involvement results in a rapid flattening of the vertebral body (vertebra plana).

Histopathologically,Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (coffee-beanappearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli.Birbeck granulesare seen in the cytoplasm.The tumour cells specifically expressHLA-DR, S-100, and CD1aandlangerin (CD207)markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhans cells with folded nuclei.

The presence of Birbeck granulesin the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racketlike appearance. Itcontains the proteinlangerin (CD207). It isseen on electron microscopy. The image below showsBirbeck granules on electron microscopy seen in LCH.

The below image shows lytic lesion of skull seen in LCH.

Option A: Rosai-Dorfman syndrome is otherwise calledsinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy.Rosai-Dorfman disease isnot a histiocytic neoplasm. It is anidiopathicdisease characterized by Painless lymphadenopathy, usually of cervical nodes. The disorder predominantly affects children, adolescents, and young adults. It may present with nonspecific symptoms and management mostly involves observation rather than specific treatment.

Option B: Kimura diseaseis s a chronic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Juvenile xanthogranulomais a non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurring in early infancy and childhood. It presents asreddish-brown papularlesions, which evolve to become orange. The lesions are most frequently seen in the face, scalp, and upper torso. They may be single or multiple lesions. Single lesions are the most common. The characteristic multinucleated giant cell, Touton cell is observed in 85% of juvenile xanthogranulomas.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented with skin-coloured umbilicated nodules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans.

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, and pink to skin-coloured umbilicated papules. A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

Tzanck smear: intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies.

Microscopic examination: Cuplike verrucous epidermal hyperplasia and Molluscum bodies: large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum.

Molluscum bodies contain numerous virions.

questions.solution:
The eosinophilic-appearing cells marked as A are the parietal cells. Their absence does not present as  Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome. Instead, their proliferation presents as Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome. The cells marked as B are Chief cells. 

Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumours. Gastrinomas are almost always found in the small intestine or pancreas. The most remarkable feature found in the stomach is an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies that impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF), which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

 

Since parietal cells secrete gastric acid, their absence results in defective gastric acid secretion, a condition known as achlorhydria.

Related Pearl: Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

  • Unregulated gastrin release from a non β cell endocrine tumor (gastrinoma)
  • Gastrinomas may be sporadic (M/C) or may be associated with MEN 1 syndrome
  • Females are more commonly affected, between 30-50 years
  • Long-standing hypergastrinemia leads to hyperchlorhydria
  • Peptic ulcer is the most common clinical manifestation
  • Clinical situations that should create suspicion of gastrinoma:
    • Ulcers in unusual locations (second part of the duodenum and beyond)
    • Refractory ulcers
    • Postoperative ulcer recurrence
    • Ulcers presenting with frank complications
    • Ulcers in the absence of H. pylori or NSAID ingestion
  • Diarrhoea is seen in 50% patients
  • The first step in evaluation is to obtain a fasting gastrin level
  • A BAO >15meq/h in the presence of hypergastrinemia is considered pathognomonic of ZES
  • BAO/MAO > 0.6 (BAO = basal acid output) (MAO=maximal acid output)
  • PPIs are the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with intussusception and was taken up for surgery. He was found to have multiple polyps. The resected section was sent for histopathology and the whole mount image of the specimen is given below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature of intussusception and multiple polyps and the histologic picture showing anarborizing pattern of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands are suggestive ofPeutzJeghers Syndrome,whichis a type of hamartomatous polyp of the small intestine.

It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract and melanosis of the mouth and the lips.

Clinical features:

  • Hamartomatous polypsof the intestinal tract
  • Hyperpigmentationof the buccal mucosa, lips, perianal skin, and digits
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk forcancer of the intestinal tract, with cancers reported throughout the intestinal tract,from the stomach to the rectum.
  • Increased risk forextraintestinal malignant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Management:

  • Surgery is indicated in cases where there is bleeding, obstruction, intussusception, or adenomatous changes of the polyp.
  • If surgery is done for these indications attempts should be made to remove as much as polyps as possible.
  • Regular screening with endoscopic studies should be done due to the increased risk of malignancies.
  • Screening of other malignancies like breast and cervix are also important.

Other options

Option A:Tubulovillous adenomaare a mixture of tubular and villous adenomas. They consist of small, pedunculated polyps composed of rounded or tubular glands and larger, sessile polyps which are covered by slender villi. These adenomas are characterized microscopically by the presence of epithelial dysplasiathe hallmarks of which are nuclear hyperchromasia, elongation and stratification.

Option C: Adenocarcinoma presents with occult bleeding, changes in bowel habits, or cramping and left lower quadrant discomfort. Morphologically, they present as polypoid, exophytic masses or annular lesions that produce napkin-ring construction and luminal narrowing. Microscopically, these tumours consist of tall columnar cells with elongated, hyperchromatic nuclei and necrotic debris in the gland lumen.

Option D: Hyperplastic polypmost commonly found in the left colon are smooth, nodular protrusions of the mucosa, often on the crests of mucosal folds. Histologically, they are composed of mature goblet and absorptive cells with a serrated surface architecture.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling. Investigations for testicular tumours  revealed that LDH was raised but AFP was within normal limits. Following orchidectomy, the following histological picture was observed. Which of the following  is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, high LDH with normal AFP levels, and the given histology picture showing fried egg appearance are highly suggestive of testicular seminoma.

In yolk sac tumors and embryonal carcinoma, AFP is elevated whereas in teratoma LDH is normal. 

Seminoma is the most common testicular tumour. It is common in men between 20-40 years of age.

The patients usually present with a painless testicular lump. If a testicular tumour is suspected, blood samples are taken from the patient for the evaluation of the tumour markers (hCG, LDH, and AFP), and a high inguinal orchidectomy is performed for diagnosis.

Further treatment of seminoma depends on the stage of the tumor. Stage I tumors, whose levels of tumor markers decline after orchidectomy may not require further treatment. Stage II-IV tumors require radiotherapy and chemotherapy. The chemotherapeutic agents used are bleomycin, etoposide, and platin-based agents (BEP).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who had a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing dies of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was a non-smoker and non-alcoholic.  The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
questions.solution:
The above gross specimen shows emphysematous damage involving enlargement of entire acinus suggestive of panacinar emphysema, which is caused due to alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency.

In panacinar (pan lobular) emphysema, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin (α1AT) is a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes. α1AT deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding. The liver is affected due to the accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. It presents as chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, or hepatocellular carcinoma. Liver biopsy shows round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes that are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. 

Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase, causing panacinar emphysema. This occurs at an earlier age and is of greater severity if the individual smokes. In this type, the acini from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal alveoli are uniformly enlarged.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling in the upper diaphyseal part of the tibia. X-ray of the swelling showed a periosteal reaction. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and mic 2. What is the likely diagnosis?

The given clinical scenario along with the image showingsmall round blue cells andimmunohistochemistry (IHC) positive for synaptophysin and mic-2 point to a likely diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma.

Ewingsarcomais the 2nd most commonbone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually<20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance.

It commonly involves thediaphysisof the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus and flat bones of the pelvis. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have t(11:22).

Patients present withpainful enlarging mass, fever, and anaemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes.These cells are of neuroectodermal origin and have minimal cytoplasm and abundant glycogen. When they are arranged around a central fibrillary core in the form of clusters, the appearance is termedHomer-Wright rosettes.Immunohistochemistry is usuallypositive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

Given below is the histopathological appearance ofEwing sarcoma.

As tumor cells are rich inglycogen,they stain positive for periodic acid Schiff (PAS) stain however, theystain negativelyforreticulin.

Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance (shown below).

Option A: Osteosarcomais themost common primary malignancyof bone. The histological features of osteosarcoma includepleomorphic cellswith hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant mitoses. The diagnosis is definitive with the presence ofmalignant tumor cellsproducing unmineralizedosteoidor mineralized bone arranged in atypically fine, lacelike pattern.

X-ray showsperiosteal reactionand it may take the form of aCodman's triangleor it may have a sunray appearanceas shown below.

Option C: Neuroblastomais a tumor of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla. It is derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. On histopathology,small round blue cells are seen. These cells areconcentrically arranged around afaintly eosinophilic fibrillary material (neuropil). This appearance is calledHomer-Wright pseudorosettes

Option D: Osteoclastoma isalso known as a giant cell tumour. The tumor cells are primitive osteoblast precursors and express high levels of RANKL. Histologically, the tumors consist of osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. These cells are usually present against a backdrop of mononuclear stromal cells as shown below.

The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumour showing the typicalsoap bubble appearance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same?

choices.text: Supra basal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
The direct immunofluorescence image showing fish net pattern is diagnostic of pemphigus where the antibodies are against the desmosomal adhesion proteins, not hemidesmosomes.

Antibodies against hemidesmosomes that link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement membrane are seen in bullous pemphigoid.

Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmosomes that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium. In pemphigus vulgaris, the cells immediately above the basal layer of the epidermis are involved, leading to the characteristic suprabasal acantholytic blister.

Variants of pemphigus are:

  • Pemphigus Vulgaris,
  • Pemphigus Vegetans,
  • Pemphigus foliaceous,
  • Pemphigus Erythematosus,
  • Paraneoplastic Pemphigus 

 

All forms of pemphigus are autoimmune diseases caused by IgG autoantibodies against desmogleins that disrupt intercellular adhesions resulting in the formation of blisters.

By direct immunofluorescence, lesions show a characteristic net-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits.

The common histologic denominator in all forms of pemphigus is Acantholysis. Acantholytic cells dissociate from one another, lose their polyhedral shape and become rounded.

questions.text: Which of the following heart tumours exhibit the histologic pattern as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given histological slide shoes abundant spider cells. They are seen in Rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic processing often artifactually reduces the abundant cytoplasm to thin strands that stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane, an appearance referred to as “spider” cells.

 Rhabdomyoma:

  • Most frequent primary tumor of the pediatric heart
  • 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis, with mutations in the tumor-suppressor genes TSC1 and TSC2.
  • Usually multiple and prefer ventricles preferentially
  • Often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas

questions.text: The following is a histopathological image of the thyroid mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows the presence ofamyloid-rich stroma(pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from theparafollicular C cells. Most of MTC aresporadic.Some areassociated with inheritable syndromes likefamilial MTC,MEN2A,andMEN2B,all of which are secondary toRET genemutations.

Most patients present at5060 yearsand have afemale preponderance. MTC secretescalcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen(CEA), andadrenocorticotrophic hormone(ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhoeadue to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitusdue to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis

Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen andamyloid stroma.Raised calcitonin and CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass helps in diagnosis.

Other options:

Option B:The image below shows Orphan Annie-eye nuclei with central clearing and margination of chromatin in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option C:Follicular carcinoma thyroid on histopathology may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid (resembling normal thyroid gland) or sheets of cells without colloid.

Option D:Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology, including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma.
  • Most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 
  • Mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade; more common in women than men (2:1)
  • Usually cold nodule on the scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with the fibrovascular stalk, Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes: Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves.
  • Lymph node metastasis is common
  • Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma.
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion
  • Most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

More common in iodine-deficient areas

Mean age of presentation is 50 years

Commonly present as solitary thyroid nodules

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions

Malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion

Associated with P53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS 

miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346) are associated with follicular carcinoma

Histology:

  • Usually solitary lesion
  • Encapsulated
  • Has uniform micro follicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumor thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere.

The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumor recurrence because this thyroid protein should be barely detectable in a patient who is free of disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal distension and intermittent fever. Peripheral smear findings were normal. A tumor was resected and the histopathology image of resected lymph node is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical and histopathological findings the most likely diagnosis is Castleman disease.

The lymph node has multiple areas of follicular hyperplasia(germinal centres) with the vascular core.

Castleman disease (Angiofollicular lymph node hyperplasia) is a heterogeneous group of lymphoproliferative disorders.

Both HHV-8-associated MCD(multicentric Castleman disease) and UCD(unicentric Castleman disease) and HHV-8-negative/idiopathic MCD (iMCD) have elevated levels of human interleukin (IL)-6.

There are 3 major histological subtypes:

  1. Hypervascular( Unicentric Castleman disease): small, regressed or atrophic germinal centres, “onion skin appearance of mantle zone around germinal centres, Lollipop appearance: blood vessels radially penetrate atrophic germinal centres.
  2. Plasma cell subtype (can be multicentric or unicentric): hypertrophic germinal centres, increased vascularity.
  3. Mixed variant (multicentric): a mix of hypervascular and plasma cell subtype features in the same lymph node.

Patients with multicentric disease present with multiple enlarged lymph node regions. All patients have systemic symptoms like night sweats, weight loss, weakness, and fatigue. Hepatosplenomegaly is present in most patients.

Hodgkins's lymphoma has characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells in sections of a lymph node.

questions.text: The following is the bone marrow biopsy of a 60-year-old man with easy fatiguability,  back pain, and multiple lytic lesions in the skull. Likely diagnosis is______
questions.solution:
The clinical history along with the biopsy picture showing Russell bodies is suggestive of multiple myeloma. 

Russell bodies are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins. It is characteristic of the distended endoplasmic reticulum in multiple myeloma.

Clinical features

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Renal failure -Acute oliguric or non-oliguric kidney failure may be present due to hypercalcemia, hyperuricemia, light-chain cast injury, or primary amyloidosis
  • Pallor and soft tissue masses
  • Fever occurs with infection
  • Patients may have neurologic signs related to neuropathy or spinal cord compression
  • Hyperviscosity syndrome (mucosal bleeding, vertigo, nausea, visual disturbances, alterations in mental status, hypoxia)

Bone marrow biopsy shows round or oval cells with an eccentric nucleus composed of coarsely clumped chromatin, a densely basophilic cytoplasm, and a perinuclear clear zone containing the Golgi apparatus.

PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions containing Ig seen in some of the plasma cells are called Dutcher bodies.

Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm are called flame cells.

questions.text: A young sexually active male presented with multiple polypoid growths over his penis. Histopathological picture of an excised lesion is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows papillary (villous) architecture with acanthosis and koilocytosis of squamous epithelium, which are characteristic findings of condyloma acuminatum.

Condyloma acuminatum is a benign warty lesion that occurs in the anogenital region. It is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 (most frequent) and 11, which are sexually transmitted.

Grossly, they consist of single or multiple sessile or pedunculated, red papillary excrescences on the coronal sulcus and the inner surface of the prepuce.

Microscopically, the characteristic features include the following:

  • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma
  • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening)
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is characteristic of HPV infection.
  • No evident dysplasia

Other options:

  • Condyloma lata is a maculopapular/nodular lesion seen in secondary syphilis.
  • Bowen's disease is carcinoma in situ of penis is characterized by hyperproliferative epidermis and dysplastic epithelium.
  • Verrucous carcinoma, also known as very well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, shows hyperkeratotic and acanthotic papillae with a broad pushing base, keratin pearls, and dense inflammatory cell infiltrate.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a liver biopsy specimen from a patient with liver disease. The following finding is noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis along with intraparenchymal cholestasis, which is suggestive of fatty liver. This condition can occur due to alcoholism.

The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on hematoxylin and eosin staining.

A few causes of fatty liver are as follows:

  • Alcoholism - most common cause in developed countries
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) - associated with diabetes and obesity
  • Toxins
  • Malnutrition
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Anoxia

Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism. It may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys.

The most common form of lipid accumulation is triglycerides. Other forms of lipid that can be accumulated include cholesterol, cholesterol esters, and phospholipids.

questions.text: An autopsy of the lung of a female patient, who died of complications post-delivery, is shown in the histological image below.  What could be the pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells in the pulmonary arteriole which is characteristically seen in amniotic fluid embolism(AFE).

AFE is a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiorespiratory collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The underlying cause is the infusion of amniotic fluid or fetal tissue into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or rupture of uterine veins.

Findings at autopsy include:

  • Substances in the maternal pulmonary micro-vasculature
    • Squamous cells shed from fetal skin
    • Lanugo hair
    • Fat from vernix caseosa
    • Mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract 
  • Marked pulmonary edema
  • Diffuse alveolar damage
  • Presence of fibrin thrombi in many vascular beds due to DIC

Other options:

  • Aggregates of platelets represent thrombosis.
  • Fat globules are seen in fat embolism, usually after severe trauma. 
  • Gas bubbles in vessels from air embolism can be a rare event in some obstetric procedures, but it is an unlikely event in natural deliveries.

questions.text: A nephrectomy specimen of a 40-year-old man showed the following histological picture. The familial cancer syndrome most likely to be associated with this type is  ____________

choices.text: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image is of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is most likely to be associated with Birt–Hogg–Dube

Chromophobe carcinoma is thought to arise from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. It is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels. 

Cytogenetic examination of the tumor shows multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy. It has an excellent prognosis compared to clear cell and papillary cancers. 

Close differential diagnoses are as follows:

  • Oncocytoma: They also consist of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. However, they do not show perinuclear halo.
  • Clear cell RCC: Pale eosinophilic cytoplasm in chromophobe RCC distinguishes it from the clear appearance of the cytoplasm due to the accumulation of glycogen and lipids in clear-cell RCC.

Other options:

  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome: Papillary RCC
  • Tuberous sclerosis: Angiomyolipoma
  • Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome: Clear-cell RCC
